comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I read one time that before that match some of the dignitaries including Collins had a bit of a puck around and that he (Colins) showed great skill at doubling on the ball overhead and seemed to be a proficient hurler.  Doubling is the art of striking the ball in mid flight to drive it further on or to potentially score without catching or slowing the ball down and takes great skill and hand to eye coordination!  Do you see the Kilkenny player on his mobile phone telling the folks back home that he has met the "Big Fella"?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] A good story anyway (about the doubling)! Everyone I've shown this photo to has laughed about the Kilkenny player on "his mobile"...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: I wonder if he actually played wearing those sock suspenders.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] It is very odd. All of his team mates have proper thick knee length socks. Do you think he got on the train or bus to Dublin without his playing socks and had to wear his normal ones?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Given how difficult it was to travel in those days and the risks that were still there it may be that he was a former player who was pressganged into the role.  It would not have been uncommon for less well off people to play in their street clothes and I saw matches in the 50's where guys in shirts, trousers and football boots played full games!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: This just in from one of our NLI Facebook people, whose grand uncle played in this match for Kilkenny, though unfortunately he was out of shot. His name was Martin "Roundy" Lalor and "he got the name Roundy because of a move he did when playing. Whenever he'd fall he'd do a little roll and come back out of it in a standing position. He won the All Ireland in 1922 and later went out to be a Sliotair maker of some renown".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Yer right,those cellphone charges could impoverish anyone.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Michael Collins addresses the Kilkenny team before the Leinster Final against Dublin, Sept 1921. From left: Paddy Donoghue(Dicksboro), Mattie Power(Dicksboro), Dick Grace(Tullaroan), Michael Joyce(Callan), Martin Egan(Threecastles), Bill Kenny(Lisdowney), Jack Holohan(from Johnstown, played with Tullaroan), Michael Collins and Harry Boland. Collins and Boland(Chairman, Dublin County Board and Sinn Féin TD for Roscommon), though great friends, found themselves on opposite sides in the Civil War which would claim both of their lives within a year. www.dicksborogaa.com/paddy-odonoghue.php This caption is to do with an edit of the above photo starting with the man with his hand on the top of hurl and finishing with Mr Boland.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: multitext.ucc.ie/viewgallery/1308 UCC have this captioned as Michael Collins addressing players before throwing in the ball at Croke Park. The occasion was the Kilkenny vs Tipperary All Ireland Final, 1922. It's wrong of course.
